dt.t: Many a pursued man fell before his {wi}nemesis{/wi} in the streets …

dt: {bc}a formidable and usually victorious {d_link|rival|rival:1} or opponent

dt.t: The team was defeated by its old {wi}nemesis{/wi}.
… pursue them with the {wi}nemesis{/wi} of outraged humanity.
A {wi}nemesis{/wi} of humankind since the first hand slapped the first cheek, mosquitoes have bitten their way into the American experience …

quotes.t: Thus, once surgeons implant the new graft, tissue rejection—the unforgiving {qword}nemesis{/qword} of most transplant attempts—occurs in only 3% to 5% of cases.
In the beginning were the words, winged at first until, paralysed, they fell to earth and were imprisoned by their {qword}nemesis{/qword}, the alphabet.
Japan and Iraq have been floated as possible successors for the role once filled by Amercia's old {qword}nemesis{/qword}, the Soviet Union …
On just the kind of putt that had been a career-long {qword}nemesis{/qword}, he kept his head perfectly still and knocked the ball squarely in the hole.

et: borrowed from Latin, borrowed from Greek {it}némesis{/it} "retribution, righteous anger, blame," probably derivative (with {it}-esis,{/it} analogically extended form of {it}-sis, -tis,{/it} suffix of action nouns) of {it}némein{/it} "to apportion, distribute" {ma}{mat|nimble|}{/ma}
shortdef: the Greek goddess of retributive justice
one that inflicts retribution or vengeance
a formidable and usually victorious rival or opponent
